key_points: Kamala Harris became the first female U.S. vice president and also the first Black woman and person of South Asian descent to hold the office.
Harris highlighted the moment as exemplifying 'American aspiration' in her remarks at the Lincoln Memorial.
She was sworn in by Supreme Court Justice Sonia Sotomayor, using a Bible that belonged to Thurgood Marshall, and escorted to the podium by Capitol Police Officer Eugene Goodman.
Her inauguration is seen as a significant moment in American history, representing progress in both gender and racial equality.
Harris' diverse background is emphasized as reflective of many Americans' stories, bringing important perspectives to the administration.
She presided over the Senate as Vice President for the first time, swearing in three new Democratic senators.
Harris had served as a Senator from California before becoming vice president and had run for the presidency herself.
Her historic inauguration was celebrated by members of the Alpha Kappa Alpha sorority and others across the country.
President Joe Biden mentioned her historic election in his inaugural address, marking it as a sign of progress.
Experts believe Harris' vice presidency will redefine political power in America and stress the significance of Black womenâ€™s leadership.
spokespersons: Lateefah Simon (civil rights advocate and friend of Harris)
Elizabeth Shelby (member, Alpha Kappa Alpha sorority)
Martha S. Jones (professor of history, Johns Hopkins University)
